item.title: [DERBY-1535] Trial 2 for DERBY-550, improve use of Engine from NetworkServer and reduce memory usage
item.description:
Through DERBY-1513, Trial 1 for DERBY-550,
it was suggested that NetworkServer seems to use Engine inefficiently and use too much of memory.

This task try to improve the use of Engine from NetworkServer and try to reduce memory usage.
item.summary: Trial 2 for DERBY-550, improve use of Engine from NetworkServer and reduce memory usage

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.

comments.comment:
Reading the code of NetworkServer, it was found that PreparedStatement.setBytes was used.

Here, I hypothesize that PreparedStatement.setBytes needs more memory than PreparedStatement.setBinaryInputStream.
Based on that hypothesis, I change call of PreparedStatement.setBytes to PreparedStatement.setBinaryInputStream.

Measured result was not different from referential result in DERBY-1504.

However, with this patch, OutOfMemoryError was not thrown from NetworkServer in the configuration of -Xmx256m.
Without this patch, OutOfMemoryError was found in the same configuration of -Xmx256m as written in http://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/DERBY-1513#action_12421379.
// However again, OutOfMemoryError happened at the client side....
// But it is not at server side.

I applied patch of both DERBY-1513(Trial-1) and DERBY-1535(Trial-2).

With this patch, OutOfMemoryError did not happen at NetworkServer in the configuration of -Xms32m -Xmx128m.
//However , OutOfMemoryError happened at the Client....

There were different in the measured result from the referential result in DERBY-1504, though it was not clear whether memory usage was improved ...
At least, the result shows that behavior of memory usage is different from before.
//In my view, it seems like that chart of memory usage is more healthy than before .....

I think this patch would improve memory usagein NetworkServer to some extent.....

This problem shouuld be resolved in this issue.

I think this problem happen because setBinaryStream of Engine is not called when setBinaryStream of Network Driver is called with null value.

I start fix it.

Surveying the source code, it seems to have something to do with difference between PreparedStatmement.setNull and PreparedStatement.setBinaryStream(null)....

I'm not sure whether we can distinguish them in drda architecture.

Moreover, I came to have a question whether it is should be allowed to call setBinaryStream with null value.
Existence of setNull method may implicitly indicate setXXXX method should not be called with null value.
However, taking setXXXX method with null value as error would have much of impact to the existing applications ...

Now, I just have read source code and there exists somethink not clear yet.
It seems to be needed to trace execution of program to know the fact more clearly.

I will continue to survey and report the result.

I think there could be a problem here:

DRDAConnThread:

  • ps.setBytes(i+1, paramBytes);
    + ps.setBinaryStream(i+1,
    + new ByteArrayInputStream(paramBytes),
    +

If paramBytes is null, it would previously be interpreted by the engine as there is a NULL value inserted into the database.
When creating a new ByteArrayInputStream, I guess it would be interpreted as inserting no data into the BLOB (if the paramBytes is null), or maybe a NullPointerException gets thrown

Reading the code, the parameter of paramBytes seems not be null.
Instead, ps.setNull method seems to be called in DRDAConnThread.parseSQLDTA_work method.

However I can't conclude only by reading the source code.
Too much "seems to be" is in my report yet. *(
Current my recognition is that we need to trace execution of the program using jdb.

Continuing survey, I found the type compatibility problem around null value typed as InputStream seems to be not so tiny problem.
